A brief history of my time...

2020 (now)

Learning TypeScript for side projects. Currently building a full stack application using Vue.js and Node.js.

2020, June 1st

Continuation of the CapaCiTi internship... I was deployed to a CapaCiTi partner that gave us a 6 month work experience. I worked as a Django backend developer who dabbled in PHP per the requirements of the software we built using Wordpress just to push out an MVP.

2019, December 3rd

I signed a contract at CapaCiTi. Seemingly, all my efforts paid off and I got an internship for the first interview I've ever been on. The beginning of promising things, I even became web development team lead in the first half of the internship as we were building a website for a school that is digitizing.

2019, August

This period of my life was heavily inspired a book I hold very near and dear to my heart...Python Tricks: A Buffet of Awesome Python Features. It laid some of the foundations that started me on my journey to learning Django, especially the section on Classes & Object Oriented Programming. I also wish someone told me to have a stronghold on version control and that building projects was the best way to learn programming. Again, lessons learned... Also, with the discovery that I can be compensated for my writing code, I put in even more effort to learn about the industry as a whole. I contemplated being a freelance developer, a YouTuber, or an employee. Since I didn't know much, I vied for freelance because of the flexible schedule it offered. Not to be though...

2019, February

There are layers to this thing. Data structures and algorithms have made me a better programmer and abstract as they are, they have made me enjoy programminng a lot more because I had a look under the hood. The books which have been the most influential are How Computers Work: The Evolution of Technology, The Computer Book: From The Abacus to Artificial Intelligence, 250 Milestones in the History of Computer Science, Eloquent JavaScript and Computer Science Distilled. All I needed to feel comfortable with programming was solidified around this time.

2018, July

What has two thumbs and doesn't know what to study next after Python ? This guy! (referring to me) To be honest, learning JavaScript right after Python was a mistake. I still weep to this day. I should have asked for directions again. I thought I had figured it out. The truth is that in programming, especially in programming you are always figuring it out. All was not lost though, I course corrected and used a book called HTML and CSS: Build and Design websites by John Duckett. With lessons learned, I used another book by the same author called JavaScript & jQuery. Boom! Just like that front end web development on lock. Or so I thought...I still had to go through Mount React.

2018, early March

My journey to relearn programming after a 10 year hiatus begins here with Python. I had asked for advice on coding forums and the advice I was given was that I should have a timeline. We live in a world of abundance and there was so much information to even start. But I dialled in into one course and one book. Less is more.
